text: So hi again.

What are we're
going to do now is

we're going to have a
look at R. Doing data

analysis these days definitely
requires a very good computing
environment.

And there's lots around,
but from my point of view,

R is probably the best
environment these days.

R is free, as we've
mentioned before,

and it's got a vast
range of capabilities.

And it's got quite a
steep learning curve,

but the more you learn, the
more capable you become.

So R allows you to do all kinds
of basic operations on data,

and it's also got lots
of built-in packages.

And once you learn R,
you'll discover it's also
got very beautiful graphics.

And after a while,
you will find that you

start writing functions yourself
and expanding your abilities.

So really R and/or
tools like R are

fundamental to doing
good data analysis
and statistical modeling.

And so we're making this a
central part of this course.

So what I'm doing
here, is I'm actually

running R in another free
program called RStudio.

So that's just an
environment for running R

and for developing
presentations in R,

and it's convenient for giving
a presentation of this kind.

So we'll now go to an
introductory session in RStudio,

and I'll just show you
some of the features of R.
So here we are.

You'll see I've got a script
in the RStudio session

in the top left panel, and
in the bottom left panel,
there's the R working session.

And what's going
to happen is, I'm

going to click on commands
that I've pre-entered,

and they'll get sent to the R
session window and executed.

Now of course, I
could have tried

to do this live and just
type in the commands,

but I don't touch-type, and
that would have been painful
for you and me.
So here we go.

So the first thing
we'll do is just

see working with basic
vectors and matrices.

So here we assign three
numbers to a vector x.

And you see the commands
gone down below.

And if we just type x,
it will print the vector.

And there we see
the three numbers.

Now there's many ways
of creating vectors.

So here's another way making
a sequence, starting from 4,

and having length 3,
and in steps by 3.

So that's a natural thing
one would want to do.

This command, Seek is
actually very useful,

and if you want to find out
more about it in R the way

to get help on
functions and objects,

is to put a question mark in
front, so we do question mark,

Seek, and in RStudio
on the right panel,

we see a panel comes up giving
us all the options for Seek,

and you'll see there's quite a
few options in the command Seek

that let you make
sequences in flexible ways.
If we type y, we see the values.

And as you might have
expected, we see 4, 7 and 10.

So now we've got two vectors, x
and y, both of the same length,

and now we can do
things with them.

And R does vector
operations in parallel.

So if we say x plus y, even
though they're both vectors,

we get the sum of those two
vectors element by element.

And likewise, other operations,
x slash y means x divide y,

and it does element-wise
division of the elements.

And you can do x to the
power y, and it will
do element-wise exponentiation.

Ooh, that gave us a rather
big number over there.

So that's some simple
operations for creating vectors.

What about accessing
elements of vectors?

Well, so there's a subscript
in convention in R using,
square braces.

So x square brace 2 gives
us the second element of x.

If we go x square
brace 2, colon 3, that

says we want the elements of
x, starting from element 2,

and ending at element 3, so
it gives us the two values.

And a very convenient
option in R for subsetting

is to put negative
signs in subscripts.

So x minus 2 means remove
the element 2 from x
and return the subsetted vector.
And so there we see that's done.

And you can remove more
than one element at a time.

And so here we moving the
collection of indices, 1 and 2,

and they can be an arbitrary
collection of indices,

and that just gives us
a vector of length 1.

Something to note,
there's no scalars in R,
everything's a vector.

So a scalar is just
a vector of length 1.
So those are vectors.

The next higher up object we're
interested in are matrices.
matrices is a case of an array.

You can have high-dimensional
arrays as well.

In R. A matrix is
a two-way array.

And here's a simple
way of making a matrix.

So here we've got z
is equal to a matrix,

and we give it the
numbers 1 to 12.

So the first argument
is, are there
actual numbers in the matrix?

And then we give it the
dimensions, 4 and 3.

So we want to make a 4 by
3 matrix, and there it is.

And so you see it's taken the
numbers in column order, which
is the convention in R.

And so now just
like with vectors,

we can subset
elements of a matrix.

So here we want to see
the third and fourth row,

and the second and third
column, and there we go.

And if you just put a comma
and ignore the first index,
you'll just get the columns.

So this gives us the second
and third column of z,

and there's the
first column of z.

Now, notice what's
happened, when

we took just the first column
of, z that became a vector,

and it actually dropped
its matrix status.

Sometimes that's convenient,
but a lot of the time

it's not, especially
when you're programming

and you don't want
to accidentally lose
a status of a matrix.

So the matrix subsetting
has an argument drop.

And here we say
drop equals false,

and it keeps that
1 column matrix
as a matrix and not a vector.
So there's various functions.

You can query the dimension
of a matrix, so dim of z

gives you the dimensions
of the matrix.

So those are vectors
and matrices.

Ls is a very nice
command, It tells you

what you have available
in your working directory.

And so we've got a number
of variables there.

The ones we've just
made are x, y, and z.

You can clean up your
working directory.

So for example, you can use
the rm command to remove y,
and here we see y is gone.
So that's making data directly.

There's other convenient ways,
especially in statistics, you're

going to often be doing
simulations to test out routines

and to test out ideas, and
so we need a good suite
of tools for generating data.
So runoff is random uniform.

So this command will create
50 random uniforms 01.

and our norm is random
norm, random Gaussian,

random normal variables,
it will create

50 standard random
normal variables.

And let's look at a
plot of these variables.

And so we plot x
and y, and there we
get a plot on the right.

Now, I must say, R graphics
is really well designed.

One doesn't think too much
about the design of graphics,

but a lot goes into it, such as
aspect ratios, how much space

to put around the points
on a plot between the edge

of the points and
the axes, just things

like spacing of the axes,
how many ticks and so on.

It all seems like trivial
details, but it's not.

And this has been carefully
thought of and designed,

and, therefore, R
graphics, I think,
are particularly attractive.

Of course, I may
be a little inbred

since I've been an R and its
predecessor user for many years.

So you can put, or you
can annotate your plots,

and add all kinds of
features to your plots.

So there's the same plot, but we
change the plotting character,
and we put axis labels.

And there's many, many
options for making plots.

And the Power command allows you
to set some of these options,

some can do directly in the plot
command, and some, like layout
commands you can set with Power.

So this is one that's
often used, mf row.

It says we want to
have a panel of plots

with two rows in one
column, and so that we
do with the our mf row command.

And so now if we do the same
plot, in our plot region

you'll see it's a little
squashed up now, because we
want two plots in this region.

And so in the second
part of the region,

we're going to do
a histogram of y.

And so that division
will stay in place

until you reset it with
another mf row command.
And so there we've reset it.

So we've created data
manually, we've generated data,

using random uniform
number generators,

and we saw uniform and
normal, and there's

many other distributions
you can generate from.

So now we're going
to read in some data

that we've got in some
other system, for example,

Excel is often the place
where you store your data.

And so we're going to read that,
there's ways of doing that in R.
So we use the read.csv function.

And so this requires that
you've saved your data in comma

separated value from Excel, and
then you can just read it in R,

and it respects the
rows, and columns,

and the headings
and everything else.

And of course, you need to know
where the data ism in this case,
I know where the data is.
If not, you'll get an error.
But here we do know what it is.

And so now we can query the
data that we have just read in.

And you can see it's
got a number of columns,

and those are the
names of the variables.

And we can look at the dimension
of the data, it's 397 by 9.

And we can see
what is this object

that we've read in the class
of auto is a data frame.

And you'll learn more
about data frames,
they very valuable objects.

It's like a matrix, except that
the columns can be variables

of different kinds,
so you can have

what we call factors,
and continuous variables,

and matrices, and so on,
which is really the way

we think of observations
in statistics.

Summaries are useful
function for a data frame,

it will give you
a summary of each

of the variables
in the data frame.

And you can see it's things
like min, max and so on.

Horsepower, for example,
is a categorical variable,

so it actually gives
you all the values.

And the name of the automobile
is also categorical,

it's a factor variable,
it gives you the values.

So dataframes and summary
of dataframe is very useful.

Now you can plot the
elements of the dataframe.
So dataframe is also a list.

And you get the
elements of the list

by giving the name of the
list, which is Auto here,

and then use a dollar sign,
and then you can give the name.

So that's one way of getting
the elements of a list.

And so here we want to
plot the column cylinders

against the column
miles per gallon, mpg.

And so we access both of
those in the same way.

And so there we have
it, there's the plot.

And so you can see
that cylinders also
takes on discrete values.

And here we do cylinders
against miles per gallon.

So that's a little
cumbersome having

to do that dollar indexing of
the elements of the data frame.

So what you can actually do, is
you can attach the data frame.

And what it does is,
it creates a workspace

with all the named variables as
now variables in your workspace,

so now you can
access them by name.

And so if we do issue
the command Search,

it tells us our
various workspaces.

And there we see the
global environment

is where we've put all our
vectors like x, y, and z,

and the variables we've
created in the session.

But this data frame
that we've attached

is in the second
position here, and it's

got the variables that are
in the order data frame
available for our direct use.

And you'll see there's other
things in the Search path

as well, and these
are largely packages

at this point whose
functions we have available.

So now we can do that plot
command more directly.

And here we've plotted
cylinders and miles per gallon.

And in this case, it's
plotted it as a box plot.

And we see for each
level of cylinders,

we get a box plot of the
values for miles per gallon,

which is like a little
one-dimensional summary

of the values at that
level of cylinder.
